nexttext: This function can be assumed to be linear,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\cal L}_{\phi F}=-\frac{1}{4}B_{F}(\phi)F_{\mu\nu}F^{\mu\nu}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mrow><mi>ϕ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>B</mi><mi>F</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ϕ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mi>F</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
(where $\kappa^2=8\pi G$) since, as has been pointed out in \cite{Dvali}, the absence of such a term would require the presence of a $\phi\to-\phi$ symmetry, but such a symmetry must be broken throughout most of the cosmological evolution.

With these assumptions one can explicitly relate the evolution of $\alpha$ to that of dark energy, as in \cite{Erminia1} whose derivation we summarize here. The evolution of $\alpha$ can be written

prevtext: with the prime denoting the derivative with respect to the logarithm of the scale factor. Putting the two together we finally obtain
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{\Delta\alpha}{\alpha}(z)=\zeta\int_{0}^{z}\sqrt{3\Omega_{\phi}(z^{\prime%
})\left[1+w_{\phi}(z^{\prime})\right]}\frac{dz^{\prime}}{1+z^{\prime}}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mi>α</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>ζ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>z</mi></msubsup><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
the change of sign stems from the fact that one expects phantom field to roll up the potential rather than down. Note that in these models the evolution of $\alpha$ can be expressed as a function of cosmological parameters plus the coupling $\zeta$, without explicit reference to the putative underlying scalar field.

In these models the proton and neutron masses are also expected to vary, due to the electromagnetic corrections of their masses. One consequence of this fact is that local tests of the Equivalence Principle lead to the conservative general constraint on the dimensionless coupling parameter (see \cite{uzanLR} for an overview)

mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{\Delta\alpha}{\alpha}(z)=-\zeta\int_{0}^{z}\sqrt{3\Omega_{\phi}(z^{%
\prime})\left|1+w_{\phi}(z^{\prime})\right|}\frac{dz^{\prime}}{1+z^{\prime}}\,;" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mi>α</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ζ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi>z</mi></msubsup><mrow><msqrt><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>|</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>ϕ</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>z</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>;</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
the change of sign stems from the fact that one expects phantom field to roll up the potential rather than down. Note that in these models the evolution of $\alpha$ can be expressed as a function of cosmological parameters plus the coupling $\zeta$, without explicit reference to the putative underlying scalar field.

In these models the proton and neutron masses are also expected to vary, due to the electromagnetic corrections of their masses. One consequence of this fact is that local tests of the Equivalence Principle lead to the conservative general constraint on the dimensionless coupling parameter (see \cite{uzanLR} for an overview)
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="|\zeta_{\rm local}|<10^{-3}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>ζ</mi><mi>local</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mo><</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: therefore, the constraints on $\zeta$ obtained in \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} lead to the two-sigma indirect bound
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta\approx 10^{-3}\zeta^{2}\,;" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>≈</mo><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mi>ζ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>;</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: therefore, the constraints on $\zeta$ obtained in \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} lead to the two-sigma indirect bound
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta<{\rm few}\times 10^{-14}\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo><</mo><mrow><mi>few</mi><mo>×</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: which we can also write in a dimensionless form by dividing by the present-day Hubble parameter,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{\dot{\alpha}}{\alpha}=(-1.6\pm 2.3)\times 10^{-17}\,{\rm yr}^{-1}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mover accent="true"><mi>α</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>α</mi></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1.6</mn></mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>2.3</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>17</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mi>yr</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: This is the strongest available laboratory constraint on $\alpha$ only. Other existing laboratory constraints are weaker and also depend on other couplings. (The interested reader can find overviews of atomic clock tests in \cite{Luo,Ferreira,Ferreira2}.) For the models under consideration this translates into

mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{1}{H_{0}}\frac{\dot{\alpha}}{\alpha}=(-2.2\pm 3.2)\times 10^{-7}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>H</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mover accent="true"><mi>α</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mi>α</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2.2</mn></mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>3.2</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where $\Sigma$ denotes the sign of $(1+w_0)$, so it is $+1$ for canonical fields and $-1$ for phantom fields.
\item Astrophysical data: we will use both the spectroscopic measurements of $\alpha$ of Webb {\it et al.} \cite{Webb} (a large dataset of 293 archival data measurements) and the smaller but more recent dataset of 11 dedicated measurements listed in Table \ref{table1}. The latter include the early results of the UVES Large Program for Testing Fundamental Physics \cite{LP1,LP3}, which is expected to be the one with a better control of possible systematics. Figure \ref{fig01} depicts both of these datasets.
\end{itemize}

We use these datasets to constrain the dynamical dark energy models which will be described in the following sections. The behavior of $\alpha$ is determined by Eq.(\ref{eq:dalfa}) for canonical equations of state ($w(z)\ge-1$) and Eq.(\ref{eq:dalfa2}) for phantom equations of state ($w(z)<-1$). While in \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} we studied models whose equations of state were parametrized by a single parameter (its present day value, $w_0$) here we relax this assumption and study more general models.

For comparison, we also list here the available direct constraints on the dimensionless E\"{o}tv\"{o}s parameter, quantifying violations to the Weak Equivalence Principle. These stem from torsion balance tests, leading to \cite{Torsion}

We use these datasets to constrain the dynamical dark energy models which will be described in the following sections. The behavior of $\alpha$ is determined by Eq.(\ref{eq:dalfa}) for canonical equations of state ($w(z)\ge-1$) and Eq.(\ref{eq:dalfa2}) for phantom equations of state ($w(z)<-1$). While in \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} we studied models whose equations of state were parametrized by a single parameter (its present day value, $w_0$) here we relax this assumption and study more general models.

For comparison, we also list here the available direct constraints on the dimensionless E\"{o}tv\"{o}s parameter, quantifying violations to the Weak Equivalence Principle. These stem from torsion balance tests, leading to \cite{Torsion}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta=(-0.7\pm 1.3)\times 10^{-13}\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>0.7</mn></mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>1.3</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Both of these are quoted with their one-sigma uncertainties.

Our main interest is in obtaining constraints on $\zeta$ and the dark energy parameters. For this reason we will fix the Hubble parameter to be $H_0=70$ km/s/Mpc and the matter density to be $\Omega_{m0}=0.3$, and further assume a flat universe, so $\Omega_{\phi0}=0.7$. This choice of cosmological parameters is fully consistent with the supernova and Hubble parameter data we use.

Moreover, in \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} we have explicitly verified that allowing $H_0$, $\Omega_m$ or the curvature parameter to vary (within observationally reasonable ranges) and marginalizing over them does not significantly change our results. This should be intuitively clear: a parts-per-million variation of $\alpha$ cannot noticeably affect these cosmological parameters. It is clear that the critical cosmological parameters here are the ones describing the dark energy equation of state, as in Class I models they will be correlated with $\zeta$---cf. Eqs.(\ref{eq:dalfa}--\ref{eq:dalfa2}). We therefore consider 3D grids of $\zeta$, $w_0$ and the additional (model-dependent) parameter, and use standard maximum likelihood techniques to compare the models and the data. Flat priors on the relevant parameters will be used, unless otherwise stated.


\section{Standard dark energy}

We will start by studying canonical dark energy models in which the fraction of the dark energy density $\Omega_\phi (z)$ tends to zero at high redshift. Note that in this case the relative variation of $\alpha$ will tend to a constant in the same limit. We will study the standard CPL parametrization but will also aim to gain some insight on the degree of model-dependence of these results by considering an alternative parametrization.

\subsection{CPL parametrization}

In the Chevallier-Polarski-Linder \cite{CPL1,CPL2} parametrization the dark energy equation of state is written as
prevtext: while from lunar laser ranging one obtains \cite{Lunar}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E15.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta=(-0.8\pm 1.2)\times 10^{-13}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>0.8</mn></mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>1.2</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></msup></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $w_0$ is its present value and $w_a$ is the coefficient of the time-dependent term. The redshift dependence of this parametrization is not intended to mimic a particular model for dark energy, but rather to allow to probe possible deviations from the $\Lambda$CDM standard paradigm without the assumption of any underlying theory. Nevertheless, we can assume that also this kind of dark energy is produced by a scalar field, coupled to the electromagnetic sector. In this model the fraction of energy density provided by the scalar field is easily found to be
prevtext:
Both of these are quoted with their one-sigma uncertainties.

Our main interest is in obtaining constraints on $\zeta$ and the dark energy parameters. For this reason we will fix the Hubble parameter to be $H_0=70$ km/s/Mpc and the matter density to be $\Omega_{m0}=0.3$, and further assume a flat universe, so $\Omega_{\phi0}=0.7$. This choice of cosmological parameters is fully consistent with the supernova and Hubble parameter data we use.

Moreover, in \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} we have explicitly verified that allowing $H_0$, $\Omega_m$ or the curvature parameter to vary (within observationally reasonable ranges) and marginalizing over them does not significantly change our results. This should be intuitively clear: a parts-per-million variation of $\alpha$ cannot noticeably affect these cosmological parameters. It is clear that the critical cosmological parameters here are the ones describing the dark energy equation of state, as in Class I models they will be correlated with $\zeta$---cf. Eqs.(\ref{eq:dalfa}--\ref{eq:dalfa2}). We therefore consider 3D grids of $\zeta$, $w_0$ and the additional (model-dependent) parameter, and use standard maximum likelihood techniques to compare the models and the data. Flat priors on the relevant parameters will be used, unless otherwise stated.


\section{Standard dark energy}

We will start by studying canonical dark energy models in which the fraction of the dark energy density $\Omega_\phi (z)$ tends to zero at high redshift. Note that in this case the relative variation of $\alpha$ will tend to a constant in the same limit. We will study the standard CPL parametrization but will also aim to gain some insight on the degree of model-dependence of these results by considering an alternative parametrization.

\subsection{CPL parametrization}

In the Chevallier-Polarski-Linder \cite{CPL1,CPL2} parametrization the dark energy equation of state is written as
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E16.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{\rm CPL}(z)=w_{0}+w_{a}\frac{z}{1+z}\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>CPL</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mi>z</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $w_0$ is its present value and $w_a$ is the coefficient of the time-dependent term. The redshift dependence of this parametrization is not intended to mimic a particular model for dark energy, but rather to allow to probe possible deviations from the $\Lambda$CDM standard paradigm without the assumption of any underlying theory. Nevertheless, we can assume that also this kind of dark energy is produced by a scalar field, coupled to the electromagnetic sector. In this model the fraction of energy density provided by the scalar field is easily found to be
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E17.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Omega_{\rm CPL}(z)=\frac{1-\Omega_{\rm m}}{1-\Omega_{\rm m}+\Omega_{\rm m}(1+%
z)^{-3(w_{0}+w_{a})}e^{(3w_{a}z/1+z)}}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>CPL</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>a</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: while that for $w_0$ is stronger
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E18.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{a}<0\qquad{\rm(68.3\%C.L.)}\,," display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>68.3</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: and that for the coupling even more so
prevtext: while that for $w_0$ is stronger
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E19.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{0}=-1.00^{+0.15}_{-0.02}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mn>1.00</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>0.02</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.15</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: and that for the coupling even more so
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E20.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\zeta=(1\pm 3)\times 10^{-6}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><mi>ζ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: Finally for the E\"{o}tv\"{o}s parameter we obtain
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E21.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\zeta=(1\pm 8)\times 10^{-6}\qquad{\rm(99.7\%C.L.)}\,." display="block"><mrow><mi>ζ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>8</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>99.7</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Compared to earlier results \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} the constraint on $w_0$ becomes weaker (due to the additional freedom provided by the largely unconstrained $w_a$) while that on $\zeta$ (and consequently that on $\eta$) become correspondingly stronger. This is to be expected since $\zeta$ is correlated with the dark energy equation of state parameters: with the equation of state allowed to be further away from a cosmological constant, larger variations of $\alpha$ also become possible, and the existing $\alpha$ measurements therefore impose a tighter constraint on $\zeta$. This effect was also noticed in the case of the forecasts discussed in \cite{Erminia2}.

\subsection{Mukhanov parametrization}

It is interesting to assess the model-dependence of the above constraints on $w_0$ and $\zeta$, and a simple way to do so is to repeat the analysis for a different parametrization of the dark energy equation of state. We will do this through a parametrization recently discussed by Mukhanov in \cite{MKH}. This was introduced in an inflationary context, but it can be trivially applied for the case of the recent acceleration of the universe.

In this parametrization (which we will refer to as MKH) the dark energy equation of state is
prevtext: Finally for the E\"{o}tv\"{o}s parameter we obtain
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E22.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta<1.6\times 10^{-14}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo><</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Compared to earlier results \cite{Pinho,Pinho2} the constraint on $w_0$ becomes weaker (due to the additional freedom provided by the largely unconstrained $w_a$) while that on $\zeta$ (and consequently that on $\eta$) become correspondingly stronger. This is to be expected since $\zeta$ is correlated with the dark energy equation of state parameters: with the equation of state allowed to be further away from a cosmological constant, larger variations of $\alpha$ also become possible, and the existing $\alpha$ measurements therefore impose a tighter constraint on $\zeta$. This effect was also noticed in the case of the forecasts discussed in \cite{Erminia2}.

\subsection{Mukhanov parametrization}

It is interesting to assess the model-dependence of the above constraints on $w_0$ and $\zeta$, and a simple way to do so is to repeat the analysis for a different parametrization of the dark energy equation of state. We will do this through a parametrization recently discussed by Mukhanov in \cite{MKH}. This was introduced in an inflationary context, but it can be trivially applied for the case of the recent acceleration of the universe.

In this parametrization (which we will refer to as MKH) the dark energy equation of state is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E23.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{\rm MKH}(z)=-1+\frac{1+w_{0}}{\left[1+\ln{(1+z)}\right]^{\beta}}\,," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>MKH</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow><msup><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mi>β</mi></msup></mfrac></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E24.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{0}=-1.00^{+0.04}_{-0.03}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mn>1.00</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>0.03</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.04</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: while for the coupling we now find
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E25.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{0}=-1.00^{+0.08}_{-0.07}\qquad{\rm(99.7\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mn>1.00</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>0.07</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>0.08</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>99.7</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

}{1-\Omega_{m}+\Omega_{m}(1+z)^{-3w_{0}}}+\Omega_{e}\left[1-(1+z)^{3w_{0}}\right]" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>EDE</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>m</mi></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>z</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E29.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{\rm EDE}(z)=-\frac{1}{3[1-\Omega_{\rm EDE}]}\frac{d\ln\Omega_{\rm EDE}}{d%
\ln a}+\frac{a_{eq}}{3(a+a_{eq})}\,;" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mi>EDE</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>z</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>EDE</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>EDE</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>;</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: which is about a factor of 3 weaker than the standard one without allowing for possible $\alpha$ variations. On the other hand, for $w_0$ we obtain

nexttext: leading to
prevtext: and finally for the coupling we obtain
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E33.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\zeta=(-1\pm 5)\times 10^{-6}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><mi>ζ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>5</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: leading to
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E34.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta<3.6\times 10^{-14}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\,." display="block"><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: which is about ten percent stronger than the flat prior case. For $w_0$ the constraints are unchanged,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E35.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Omega_{e}<0.030\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\,," display="block"><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mi>e</mi></msub><mo><</mo><mn>0.030</mn><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: which is about ten percent stronger than the flat prior case. For $w_0$ the constraints are unchanged,
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E36.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{0}<-0.97\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}" display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>0.97</mn><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: and finally the constraint on the coupling becomes weaker as well as asymmetric
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E37.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="w_{0}<-0.93\qquad{\rm(99.7\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><msub><mi>w</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo><</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>0.93</mn><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>99.7</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

nexttext: leading to
prevtext: and finally the constraint on the coupling becomes weaker as well as asymmetric
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E38.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\zeta=(-1^{+8}_{-11})\times 10^{-6}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\," display="block"><mrow><mi>ζ</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mn>1</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>11</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: leading to
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E39.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\eta<14.4\times 10^{-14}\qquad{\rm(95.4\%C.L.)}\,;" display="block"><mrow><mi>η</mi><mo><</mo><mn>14.4</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></mrow></msup><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true">  </mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>95.4</mn><mo lspace="0pt" rspace="3.5pt">%</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>.</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo>.</mo><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>;</mo></mrow></math>
